questions.question: Use the chart below and your knowledge from your reading: Why did the Presidential election of 1824 cause controversy?

choices.answer: John Quincy Adams was accused of making a corrupt bargain with Henry Clay.
Henry Clay had made secret agreements to help elect Andrew Jackson.
The President was chosen by the Senate
President John Quincy Adams was soon convicted of corruption

questions.question: In 1828, what effect did the Tariff of Abominations have on the United States under President Andrew Jackson?

choices.answer: It fostered the nation’s hatred of British business.
It fueled growing sectional differences within the country
It helped the West, which did not rely on international trade.
It favored the South’s industrial-based economy.

questions.question: How did Andrew Jackson set the stage for later economic trouble when he eliminated the second National Bank?

choices.answer: He caused inflation by having states print an oversupply of paper money
He decreased inflation by moving funds back to the first National Bank.
Moved the national bank’s funds to banks that invested in Britain.
Spent money on lands that the government owned, raising the National Debt.

questions.question: Why did tensions exist between Native American groups and white settlers?

choices.answer: Native Americans resisted settlement by attacking U.S. army.
Settlers with a larger population and more weapons attacked Native American
Native Americans received access to better land than white settlers
White settlers offered to protect Native Americans

questions.question: Use the map and the knowledge from your textbook to answer the following question. Where was Indian Territory?

choices.answer: east of the Mississippi River
south of the Blue Ridge Mountains
present-day Oklahoma
present-day Mexico

questions.question: Who benefited most from Andrew Jackson’s plan to remove American Indians to the West?

choices.answer: American Indians, who gained protection by the U.S. government
Andrew Jackson, who gained public approval as a result of his policy
American farmers, who gained millions of acres of land for settlement
Cherokee Indians, who gained a new model of constitutional government

questions.question: What aspect of Native American history became known as the “Trail of Tears”?

choices.answer: the blood that flowed from the Sauk Indians in the Black Hawk War
the forced 800-mile march Cherokee Indians made in their removal
line connecting Seminole Indian settlements up/down Florida’s east coast
the unpublished works on the Cherokee population written by Sequoya

questions.question: How does Black Hawk feel about his people’s movement to a new home?

choices.answer: Shock:"none of our people would have believed him" when describing removal
Optimistic: "no hunting grounds better than those we had"
Sadness: "miserable as the hungry, howling wolf in the prairie"
Gratitude:  as he describes "to be driven from our village"

questions.question: What where the effects of Native Americans being removed from their land?

choices.answer: There would not be many Native Americans living east of the Mississippi
They would have to adapt to living in a new environment.
Tradition in farming and hunting would need to be changed.
A lot of deaths and loss of family members on the Trail of Tears

questions.question: The National Road was the first U.S. road

choices.answer: built by the federal government.
that reached from the Atlantic to the Pacific.
built using bulldozers and steamrollers.
that was limited to commercial use.

questions.question: Why was the Erie Canal such a massive undertaking?

choices.answer: Because it was extremely long
Because it went through dense wilderness
Because a lot of the canal would be dug by hand
Because it was in Buffalo

questions.question: Why would mountain men choose to endure the harsh lifestyle of a trapper?

choices.answer: They wanted to be isolated and did not care about making a profit
They did not want to have to work hard for the money they earned.
They were rejected from traditional society and had no other option.
The sought a life of adventure and good income

questions.question: Settlers preparing to head out onto the Oregon Trail felt that it was important to

choices.answer: study the culture of Native Americans they might meet along the way.
pack lots of gear for the long journey
learn how to swim
plan an alternate route in case they got lost.

questions.question: Mormons moved from New York to the West in the early 1830s in order to

choices.answer: obey the Book of Mormon.
prosper in the fur trade.
to avoid further religious persecution
form an independent country

questions.question: Why were settlers from the United States interested in settling in Mexican Texas?

choices.answer: The best land in the United States was already taken
Texas had cheap land available
Lands in Texas were fertile and good for farming
All of the Answers

questions.question: Which of the following factors helped the Texans gain victory in the Battle of San Jacinto?

choices.answer: Frontiersman Davy Crockett joined the Texan defenses.
General Santa Anna had been imprisoned at the Alamo.
Sam Houston’s men, took the Mexican army by surprise
Prisoners at Goliad were released, adding to the Texan defenses.

questions.question: The United States was divided about whether or not to annex Texas to the Union in 1845 because it could

choices.answer: upset the balance between free and slave states.
encourage wars of independence in other border areas.
have gone against the wishes of Congress.
admitted to the British that western expansion had ended.

questions.question: Why did some Americans support James K. Polk’s interest in annexing Oregon and Texas to the Union?

choices.answer: Disputes over the U.S. border with Canada would be easier to settle.
Belief in Manifest Destiny
Both Blue and Green
westward expansion would provide the US with new economic opportunities

questions.question: What words or phrases best illustrate that Channing was against Manifest Destiny?

choices.answer: imminent [danger] to our institutions, union, prosperity, virtue, and peace
"we should lay on ourselves serious [firm] restraint..."
...for the growth of ages...
...restless people

questions.question: How did the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo, signed in 1848, affect the United States?

choices.answer: It drew the border line that divides the United States and Mexico
United States to collected $18 million in property taxes from Mexico.
It forced the United States to give up vast acres of territory in the West.
It added present day California and New Mexico to the nation.

questions.question: How did the Gadsden Purchase benefit the United States?

choices.answer: It promised to safeguard the property rights of longtime U.S. residents.
The States gained hunting rights in the area of Texas north of  Rio Grande
secured a southern route for a transcontinental railroad on American soil
Allowed the United States to purchase northern part of present day Arizona.

questions.question: Which description fits the group of people known as “forty-niners”?

choices.answer: gold-seekers from America and abroad who migrated to California
middle-aged married men with previous gold-mining experience
individual prospectors who emigrated from California to the east.
Native Americans leaving California ranches for a better life.

questions.question: What happened to San Francisco's population as a result of the Gold Rush?

choices.answer: San Francisco remained an insignificant port town on the West coast.
The population boomed during “gold fever,” but declined just as quickly.
Californios and Native Americans still outnumbered immigrants and Americans
Gold Rush transforms San Francisco from small port town to major city.
